narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I loved this course! it was so fun to dive in depth into latin America

I gained a deeper understanding of the history of Indigenous peoples in Latin America, how race and slavery have shaped the political, social, and economic development of Latin America, and the role of nationalism in identity formation in the region. I also developed stronger historical analysis skills, particularly in assimilating complicated new ideas about regions and countries I had never studied before.
Really learned a lot about the history of anthropology and its use and study in Latin America.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It would be nicer if there were more touchpoints within the class to make it such that one could evaluate themselves more easilty

The course was really strong in terms of the wide array of topics it was able to cover: we jumped from Bolivia to Cuba to Brazil in just one week. The course really pushes you to think beyond the standard conversations you may have in a history seminar, as it simply covers so many different issue areas, from gold in Colombia to Indigenous artifacts in Mexico to the history of anthropology in France. It was very intellectually challenging and made me a stronger history student. I would say one way to improve the course was that it was often hard that students were not sharing so much in class conversation  I think the course could try to bring more students into the conversation.
Really strong in the reading aspect. However, could use more facilitation in the conversation aspect.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Zoom was not ideal for this course, as one of its weaknesses was that students were not contributing so much to discussion. If we were in person, it would have been easier to carry out a conversation among all of the students. Of course, this was not Professor Echeverri's fault, as the Zoom platform makes it difficult for students and faculty alike to communicate and work together.
Because enrollment was small we were able to have conversations without stepping on each other's toes.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes it was a fun time and if its not your field its always good to try something new
Yes! It was a really great intro to the history of Latin America, and I would highly recommend to anyone who is curious and wants to learn more!
Yes! Especially someone who is looking for an up close look at ethnicity in Latin America.
